holdings.text: The settlements dated November 1, 1966 and May 13, 1967 related only to interim relief as per the Wage Board, and the workmen were at liberty to raise demands after final recommendations.

anchor.surface_text: Though there has been a very elaborate consideration by the High Court regarding the competency of the, third respondent to terminate the settlements, its ultimate decision is rested on a construction of the two settlements dated November 1, 1966 and May 13, 1967. According to the High Court, it is abundantly clear on a reading of the various clauses

holdings.reasoning_summary: Court examined clauses of settlements and fully agreed with High Court's textual construction that they pertain solely to interim relief pending Wage Board final recommendations.

holdings.text: The State Government's view that the settlements related only to interim relief is a possible one, hence the reference under section 10(1) is competent.

anchor.surface_text: As we are now on the limited question regarding the competency of the State Government to make the reference, it must be held that the, State Governments view that, the settlements related only to the interim relief is a possible one in the circumstances of this case. Hence, we cannot say that the reference made by the State Government was incompetent.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Limited to competency of reference; possible view by government suffices for power under s.10(1); no need to decide termination validity.

holdings.text: No opinion expressed on the right of the third respondent (minority union) to terminate the settlements due to factual controversy on majority representation at relevant time.

anchor.surface_text: We express no opinion on the question, regarding the right of the third respondent to terminate the two agreements in question because there is a controversy as to whether, at the relevant date, the third respondent represented the majority of the workmen bound by these agreements. The claim of the third respondent is that it represented the majority of such workmen.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Factual dispute on union's majority status to be decided by Tribunal; not for High Court/Supreme Court in writ/reference competency.

holdings.text: The appellant did not act to its prejudice on the Minister's representation, as settlements preceded by union demands and made for industrial peace; precedents on estoppel do not apply.

anchor.surface_text: None of the settlements entered into by the appellant with its workmen gives any indication that the said settlements were being made in view of the statement made by the Minister. On the other hand, we have already pointed out that every one of the settlements is preceded by a demand made, by the union concerned. It is really in the interest of industrial peace that the appellant appears to have entered into those settlements. Therefore, the deci- sions relied on by Mr. Shroff do not apply in this case.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No link between settlements and Minister's statement; demands by unions preceded; interest of industrial peace; Indo-Afghan and Century Spinning distinguished.

holdings.text: Whether Minister's statement binds government from referring disputes is debatable, but unnecessary to decide here.

anchor.surface_text: The Act gives power to the State Government to refer a dispute for adjudication. As to how far, by a Minister making a statement, the Government can be relieved of its obligation under the Act, is a debatable question.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Obiter; not reached due to facts not supporting prejudice from representation.

holdings.text: Discrimination claim regarding differential treatment vis-a-vis Indian Hume Pipe Co. not entertained as not argued before High Court.

anchor.surface_text: We find, however, from the judgment of the High Court that this question of discrimination with special reference to the Indian Hume Pipe company Ltd. has not been argued by the appellant. The inference under such circumstances is that such a contention was not pressed before the High Court. Hence we decline to go into that question.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Procedural: point not raised below, hence declined.

anchor.surface_text: In the result, the appeal fails and is dismissed. There will be no order as to costs.

None of the settlements entered into by the appellant with its workmen gives any indication that the said settlements were being made in view of the statement made by the Minister. On the other hand, we have already pointed out that every one of the settlements is preceded by a demand made, by the union concerned. It is really in the interest of industrial peace that the appellant appears to have entered into those settlements. Therefore, the deci- sions relied on by Mr. Shroff do not apply in this case.
In the result, the appeal fails and is dismissed. There will be no order as to costs.

We find, however, from the judgment of the High Court that this question of discrimination with special reference to the Indian Hume Pipe company Ltd. has not been argued by the appellant. The inference under such circumstances is that such a contention was not pressed before the High Court. Hence we decline to go into that question.
In the result, the appeal fails and is dismissed. There will be no order as to costs.
